history.content:
I can speak to this as someone who's actually taken all of this stuff. 61c aligns with a big part of EE, but NOT the 120, 106 part of it. If you found 61c SDS interesting, I think you would thoroughly enjoy EECS 151 (I've heard 152 isn't as good). You would also be served well by classes like EE 105 if you do decide to commit to circuit design.

152 isn't relevant to SP/controls/robotics. Circuits and high-level robotics SP have almost nothing to do with each other, despite technically being in the same department. That being said, college is a good time to explore your interests, and you will probably have enough time to take 151/120/106A and a bunch of other stuff if you want to explore them all.

------------

Depends what you wanna do:

-Some people think robotics is mainly just machine learning stuff like 188 and 189 stuff. For example, the advanced robotics grad class this semester is a lot of reinforcement learning and stuff

-Signals and systems and control systems (128) are really useful too

-106a and linear algebra are really useful as they involve actually programming and directing the robot (e.g. how do you get from one position to another, what can you reach, and how to program this)

-There is always hardware design, actually making the circuitry and designing the boards and such. This is where 152 is relevant

152 is great for a career in computer architecture and design. It isn't a broad class, so that's the main place you could go with it if you want. Would also be useful for systems engineering and design since the OS has to work with the computer architecture a lot, and maybe even security by taking advantage of those processes (see https://meltdownattack.com/).

children.subject: Thank you all for your answers, I'm going to continue researching what's right for me

history.content: I signed up for 152 after realizing that I found 61c very interesting. I'm looking to do some more robotics and EE classes like 120, 106A/B, etc. Is 152 relevant to that field? also what else can I do in career and beyond with 152?
history.subject: cs152 career aspects
